stem: The nurse is caring for a patient at imminent risk for suicide. Based on the information presented in the patient's chart, identify the FIVE most important actions the nurse should take *first*, in order of priority.

itemContext.sbar: Michael Evans, 32, admitted to the psychiatric unit at 03:00 post-acetaminophen overdose suicide attempt. He has a history of major depressive disorder and alcohol use disorder. He reports hopelessness after job loss and a breakup. Found by his roommate, he was brought to the ED. On admission, he was alert but anxious. Initial vitals: BP 140/90, HR 110, RR 24, SpO2 98%, Temp 99.0°F. Acetaminophen level was elevated; N-acetylcysteine was started. Continuous observation and suicide precautions ordered. He's currently restrained due to agitation. Plan: monitor vitals, administer medications, provide support. Mental status evaluation at 09:00.

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: Acetaminophen: 350 mcg/mL (Reference Range: 10-25 mcg/mL), ALT: 60 U/L (Reference Range: 7-55 U/L), AST: 70 U/L (Reference Range: 8-48 U/L), Ethanol: <10 mg/dL, CBC: Within normal limits.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: N-acetylcysteine (NAC) 140 mg/kg PO loading dose administered at 04:00. N-acetylcysteine (NAC) 70 mg/kg PO q4h x 17 doses starting at 08:00. Lorazepam 2mg IM PRN anxiety/agitation q4h PRN, last dose at 06:00.

topicTags: Mental Health: Suicide Risk & Crisis Management

rationale.correct: 1. Ensure continuous observation: The patient is on suicide precautions and exhibiting agitation, requiring constant monitoring to prevent self-harm. 2. Maintain patient safety by ensuring restraints are correctly applied: Restraints are in place due to agitation, so correct application and monitoring are crucial to prevent injury. 3. Administer PRN lorazepam as prescribed: The patient received lorazepam at 06:00. If agitation persists, another dose may be indicated to manage anxiety and prevent escalation. 4. Document the patient's behavior and interventions: Accurate and timely documentation provides a record of the patient's condition, interventions, and responses, which is essential for continuity of care. 5. Collaborate with the mental health team to review the care plan: Given the patient's imminent risk and ongoing distress, consulting with the psychiatrist and other team members is essential to refine the treatment strategy.
rationale.incorrect: Withholding fluids to prevent additional overdose is not appropriate, as the patient requires hydration and medication administration for the acetaminophen overdose. Encouraging the patient to verbalize feelings is appropriate but not the *first* action when the patient is actively agitated and at imminent risk. Initiating discharge planning is premature and inappropriate at this stage, as the patient is acutely suicidal and requires ongoing monitoring and treatment. Removing restraints immediately is unsafe as the patient continues to exhibit agitation and is at risk of self-harm. Encouraging the patient to eat a meal can be considered later, but is not the priority when the patient is actively suicidal and agitated.
clinicalPearls: Patients at imminent risk of suicide require continuous observation and a safe environment.
Restraints should be used only as a last resort and with appropriate monitoring and documentation.
Collaboration with the mental health team is crucial in managing suicidal patients.

questionTrap.trap: Many students prioritize verbal de-escalation before ensuring environmental safety and medication administration. The question emphasizes *first* actions, targeting the immediacy of risk reduction.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Carefully assess the level of immediate risk and prioritize actions that directly address safety and physiological stability before moving to less urgent interventions.

mnemonic.title: SAFE-T
mnemonic.expansion: Safety Assessment For Every Treatment (prioritize Safety, Assess risk, Facilitate treatment, Ensure ongoing monitoring, Team collaboration)
